Hi,

> >       I ask because I think the latter should be more portable across 
> problem
> >domains.  e.g. if individuals/species can enter and leave pruning
> >individually, then they can subsequently either survive or perish in the
> >population, so, as an extreme case, if you had a problem that pruning
> >_never_ helped then all pruned species would die but have no effect on the
> >outcome, because non-pruned species would always exist to continue the
> >search.  Actually, for that to be completely true, if you use a species,
> >you probably want to take a copy of it and start pruning that; whereas
> >starting/ending pruning an individual would make it a new species?
> >
> >
>One of the major benefits of pruning though is that it keeps the
>complexity of the population as a whole in check, which keeps the NEAT
>search running at an optimal speed.

Except that if the pruned species are fitter they will supplant the 
un-pruned ones and if they are not, then you don't have the option of 
pruning anyway.

Er... maybe...

Must think about it some more...

Maybe if species were allocated some analogue of runtime, then the pruned 
species would evolve faster (using less of their runtime per 
generation).  So if they _could_ come to beat the unpruned ones then they 
_would_ (being faster) but if they could not they would not (because we're 
not actually adjusting anybody's fitness due to their size).

>So if you allowed some species to
>complexify without limit you would loose this benefit. Anway, more
>details on all of this will be in my write up!

Anyway, just thinking out loud here, will be very interested when you write 
it up.

>Colin

Ian
